Award.AwardTitle: UNM Information Assurance Scholarship for Service Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The CyberCorps: Scholarship for Service (SFS) program at the University of New Mexico (UNM) prepares at least 18 highly qualified Information Assurance (IA) and security professionals for service in federal, state, local, and tribal governmental agencies. UNM's program is distinct from other IA programs in that it addresses the "application divide" between IA theory, technology and real world practice, and applies IA technology within the behavioral, organizational, and economic context of organizations. In addition to the coursework, program components include: a research seminar co-designed by UNM, Sandia National Laboratory and Intel which focuses on the Theory of Inventive Problem Solving; monthly professional development workshops; and an online learning community. UNM is a Hispanic Serving Institution with 37% of the students being of Hispanic origin and it enrolls more Native Americans than any other research university in the country (11.3%). The project defines very ambitious enrollment targets for SFS students: 40% minority and 40% female. The program results are disseminated to help replicating this model of using IA concepts and technology to directly address the behavioral, organizational and economic factors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of New Mexico (UNM) Information Assurance Scholarship for Service (SFS) program recruited, graduated, and placed 22 students in the CyberCorps during the grant period ended December 31, 2018. In addition, there are 8 students with degrees in progress, started under this grant with continued support under a renewal grant.

Diversity in mulitple forms is a hallmark of the program. One diversity aspect is the inclusion of four different Masters programs (computer science, computer engineering, information systems/assurance, and accounting) under the program umbrella. This diversity enabled UNM to recruit SFS students from a wide variety of educational and experiental backgrounds. The result is a multidisciplinary program that generated graduates with diverse skills/interests and internship/career placements in 18 different Federal agencies. Student placements span a wide range if cyber- and IA-related areas including offensive and defensive technology, intelligence, law enforcement, compliance, and policy.

The program also has signifciant gender and ethnic diversity among. Of the 30 students graduated and in-progress as of December 2018, 53.3% (16/30) are from ethnic minorities and 23.3% (7/30) are female.

The existence of the program and the presence of its highly qualified awardees had spill-over impacts for the related UNM degree programs, departments, and schools. Additional highly-qualified students, beyond those awarded scholarships, enrolled in and completed cybersecurity- and information assurance-related degrees. SFS student presence in classes and non-classroom activities raised the performance bar for all students thus improving overall program quality and extending program benefits accruing to employers well beyond the CyberCorps.

SFS student outreach activities expanded the program's impact to local businesses, non-profit organizations, and K-12 education. SFS students made presentations to K-12 students to increase their cybersecurity awareness and skills. SFS students completed security vulnerability assessment projects for many local organizations and made recommendations for improvement.

In sum, taxpayer investment in UNM's SFS program made New Mexico's and the nation's cyberspace safer and more secure.
